journal-title-group.journal-title: Journal of the American Heart Association: Cardiovascular and Cerebrovascular Disease

title-group.article-title: Study Design, Rationale, and Methodology for Promote Weight Loss in Patients With Peripheral Artery Disease Who Also Have Obesity: The PROVE Trial

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non‚Äêcommercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Overweight and obesity are associated with adverse functional outcomes in people with peripheral artery disease (PAD). The effects of weight loss in people with overweight/obesity and PAD are unknown.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The PROVE (Promote Weight Loss in Obese PAD Patients to Prevent Mobility Loss) Trial is a multicentered randomized clinical trial with the primary aim of testing whether a behavioral intervention designed to help participants with PAD lose weight and walk for exercise improves 6‚Äêminute walk distance at 12‚Äêmonth follow‚Äêup, compared with walking exercise alone. A total of 212 participants with PAD and body mass index ‚â•25‚Äâkg/m2 will be randomized. Interventions are delivered using a Group Mediated Cognitive Behavioral intervention model, a smartphone application, and individual telephone coaching. The primary outcome is 12‚Äêmonth change in 6‚Äêminute walk distance. Secondary outcomes include total minutes of walking exercise/wk at 12‚Äêmonth follow‚Äêup and 12‚Äêmonth change in accelerometer‚Äêmeasured physical activity, the Walking Impairment Questionnaire distance score, and the Patient‚ÄêReported Outcomes Measurement Information System mobility questionnaire. Tertiary outcomes include 12‚Äêmonth changes in perceived exertional effort at the end of the 6‚Äêminute walk, diet quality, and the Short Physical Performance Battery. Exploratory outcomes include changes in gastrocnemius muscle biopsy measures of mitochondrial cytochrome C oxidase activity, mitochondrial biogenesis, capillary density, and inflammatory markers.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The PROVE randomized clinical trial will evaluate the effects of exercise with an intervention of coaching and a smartphone application designed to achieve weight loss, compared with exercise alone, on walking performance in people with PAD and overweight/obesity. Results will inform optimal treatment for the growing number of patients with PAD who have overweight/obesity.

sec.title: Registration
sec.p: URL: https://www.clinicaltrials.gov; Unique identifier: NCT04228978.

award-group.funding-source: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

fn.p: This manuscript was sent to Amgad Mentias, MD, Associate Editor, for review by expert referees, editorial decision, and final disposition.

def.p: Low Intensity Exercise Intervention in PAD
Promote Weight Loss in Obese PAD Patients to Prevent Mobility Loss

body.p: Lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD) affects >230‚Äâmillion adults worldwide,1, 2 and causes significant walking impairment.2 Walking exercise is first‚Äêline therapy to improve walking performance in PAD.3 Individuals with PAD and overweight or obesity have greater functional impairment and faster functional decline than people with PAD and normal weight.4, 5, 6 Rates of obesity are increasing nationally7 and ‚âà65% of people with PAD have overweight or obesity.8, 9 In animals, obesity was associated with impaired limb perfusion10 and in humans, obesity was associated with reduced skeletal muscle mitochondrial biogenesis and activity.11 However, the effects of intentional weight loss in people with PAD who have overweight or obesity are unknown. A combined weight loss and exercise intervention may improve walking performance if weight loss improves adherence to exercise activity by making walking exercise easier, increasing calf perfusion, and improving calf mitochondrial activity and inflammation. However, weight loss may not be beneficial if weight loss exacerbates PAD‚Äêrelated sarcopenia or if the requirements of the weight loss program interfere with adherence to walking exercise.12

The PROVE (Promote Weight Loss in Obese PAD Patients to Prevent Mobility Loss) Trial was designed to compare an intervention intended to achieve weight loss combined with walking exercise to a walking exercise intervention alone. The weight loss intervention and the walking exercise intervention incorporated behavioral change methods. The primary outcome is change in 6‚Äêminute walk distance at 12‚Äêmonth follow‚Äêup. This article describes the design and methods for the PROVE Trial.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The PROVE Trial was reviewed and approved by a single Institutional Review Board through Northwestern University. All participants provide written informed consent. This clinical trial is single‚Äêblind, multicentered, and conducted at Northwestern University (Chicago, IL), the University of Minnesota (Minneapolis, MN), and Tulane University (New Orleans, LA), with the Data Coordinating Center at Wake Forest University School of Medicine (Winston‚ÄêSalem, NC). After trial completion, anonymized data and materials will be made publicly available at BioLINCC.

sec.title: Participant Identification
sec.p: Patients with established PAD or vascular laboratory testing consistent with PAD are contacted via mailed letters, messaging through patient portals, and referrals from vascular specialists. Brochures, flyers, or posters are displayed in relevant clinics. Postcards advertising the study are mailed to people aged 50‚Äâyears and older in the communities where the trial is conducted. Advertisements on buses and trains in Chicago, Minneapolis, and New Orleans are used to advertise the clinical trial. Field center investigators also identify potential participants from lists of people with PAD who participated in previous studies and expressed interest in future research. Initial eligibility screening occurs by telephone (Table¬†1).

list-item.p: (After a brief study description) Are you interested in hearing more about the study?
How did you hear about the study?

What is your date of birth?
Has a doctor ever told you that you have blockages in your leg arteries, intermittent claudication, or peripheral artery disease?
Do you get pain, discomfort, tightness, weakness, or other symptoms in your legs when you walk?

Has a doctor ever told you that you had diabetes?

What is your height?

For this study, you will be asked to attend 2‚Äì3 baseline visits and engage in an intervention for 1‚Äâyear. During the year you will be asked to attend weekly visits for the first 4‚Äâmonths. These weekly visits will transition to every other week for the 5th and 6th months of the study, and finally, to once‚Äêa‚Äêmonth sessions for the last 6 months of the study. sec.title: Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria
sec.p: Inclusion and exclusion criteria are intended to maximize both eligibility and generalizability of the randomized sample (Table¬†2). Eligible participants are people with PAD who have either overweight or obesity. Participants with overweight (ie, body mass index [BMI] 25‚Äì29.9‚Äâkg/m2) were included for the following reasons. First, prior work showed that among people with PAD, annual declines in 6‚Äêminute walk distance increased across BMI categories of normal BMI, overweight, and obesity.4 Second, prior work showed a trend across BMI categories of normal BMI, overweight, and obesity with regard to the degree of fatty infiltration of calf skeletal muscle in people with PAD.6 Third, including participants with either overweight or obesity increases generalizability of the results. Fourth, including participants who are overweight was expected to assist with recruitment. Patients who report treatment for overweight or obesity in the past 6‚Äâmonths are excluded (Table¬†2). However, patients taking drugs associated with mild‚Äêto‚Äêmodest weight loss such as metformin or glucagon‚Äêlike peptide receptor agonists to treat diabetes who report no recent treatment for weight loss are not excluded. Data on medication use at baseline and follow‚Äêup is recorded by investigators.

list-item.label: ‚Äê
list-item.p:
Presence of PAD, defined by: ‚óã
ABI ‚â§0.90 or TBI ‚â§0.70 at baseline visit‚óã
ABI >0.90 and ‚â§1.00 with a 20% or greater drop in ABI in either leg after the heel‚Äêrise test at baseline visit‚óã
ABI >0.90 at baseline visit with vascular laboratory evidence or angiographic evidence of PAD, including: ‚ñ†
TBI ‚â§0.70‚ñ†
Duplex ultrasound or angiographic evidence of ‚â•70% stenosis in lower extremity artery‚ñ†
Post heel‚Äêrise or post‚Äêexercise ABI drop in either leg of ‚â•20%‚ñ†
ABI ‚â§0.90 ‚óã
Individuals with a history of lower extremity revascularization who do not meet the criteria above and have an ABI >0.90 with ‚â•20% drop in ABI after an exercise test will be eligible if they have symptomatic PAD*

td.p: Accepted criteria for PAD in clinical practice guidelines.3

list-item.label: ‚Äê
list-item.p: BMI ‚â•25‚Äâkg/m2

tr.td: Overweight and obesity are defined as a BMI of 25‚Äì29‚Äâkg/m2 and >30‚Äâkg/m2. Observational evidence demonstrated a linear trend in association of normal BMI, overweight, and obesity with the magnitude of annual decline in 6‚Äêminute walk distance among people with PAD.4

list-item.label: ‚Äê
list-item.p: Age ‚â•18‚Äâyears

list-item.label: ‚Äê

tr.td: These criteria characterize severe or end stage PAD. Most individuals with PAD do not have severe/end stage PAD.

list-item.label: ‚Äê
list-item.p: Walking is limited by a condition other than PAD.

tr.td: The WL+EX intervention is designed to improve walking impairment caused by PAD.

list-item.label: ‚Äê

td.p: These individuals may not adhere to study

list-item.p: Major surgery, coronary or leg revascularization in the past 3 months or anticipated in the next year.

td.p: These procedures may influence functional performance, independent of study interventions.

list-item.label: ‚Äê

tr.td: These individuals have morbid obesity that requires more intensive treatment than our intervention provides.

list-item.label: ‚Äê

list-item.label: ‚Äê
list-item.p: Weight gain or loss of >25 pounds in the past 6‚Äâmonths

tr.td: The WL+EX intervention is not intended for individuals with an eating disorder. Patients with recent weight loss may have weight change independently of the study interventions.

list-item.label: ‚Äê

list-item.label: ‚Äê
list-item.p: Non‚ÄêEnglish‚Äêspeaking

list-item.label: ‚Äê
list-item.p: Visual impairment that limits walking ability

tr.td: These individuals will not be able to fully engage in the intervention.

list-item.label: ‚Äê
list-item.p: Excessive alcohol use, defined as >14 drinks/wk in men and >10 alcoholic drinks/wk in women.

tr.td: These individuals may not be able to lose weight.

list-item.label: ‚Äê
list-item.p: Currently walking regularly for exercise at a level comparable to the amount of exercise prescribed in the intervention

list-item.label: ‚Äê
list-item.p: Current participation in supervised treadmill exercise, participation in supervised treadmill exercise in the past 3‚Äâmonths or planning to participate in supervised treadmill exercise in the next year.

list-item.label: ‚Äê
list-item.p: Participation in or completion of a clinical trial in the previous 3‚Äâmonths¬ß

fn.p: ABI indicates ankle brachial index; BMI, body mass index; PAD, peripheral artery disease; TBI, toe brachial index; and WL+EX, weight loss plus exercise.

Symptomatic PAD will be defined as leg symptoms associated with exertion that resolved within 10‚Äâminutes of rest. The presence of symptomatic PAD will be determined based on the claudication questionnaire, the 6‚Äêminute walk, or principal investigator interview/discussion with the potential participant.

The run‚Äêin period can be extended to assist participants with learning the app, but participants must demonstrate ability to enter at least 800 kcal per day for at least 5‚Äâdays of the run‚Äêin period.
Potential participants may still qualify if they have had treatment for an early‚Äêstage cancer in the past 2‚Äâyears and the prognosis is excellent.

After completing a stem cell or gene therapy intervention, participants will become eligible after the final study follow‚Äêup visit of the stem cell or gene therapy study so long as at least 6‚Äâmonths have passed since the final intervention administration. After completing a supplement or drug therapy (other than stem cell or gene therapy), participants will be eligible after the final study follow‚Äêup visit provided at least 3‚Äâmonths have passed since the final intervention of the trial.

sec.p: The ankle brachial index (ABI) is performed after 5‚Äâminutes of supine rest. The systolic blood pressure is measured twice in the right brachial, dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, and left dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, and brachial arteries using a hand‚Äêheld Doppler probe. The ABI is calculated for each leg by dividing the mean of the dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pressures by the mean of the 4 brachial pressures. Participants with a borderline ABI (ie, >0.90 and ‚â§1.00) may undergo a heel‚Äêrise ABI. The heel‚Äêrise test consists of the participant performing 50 heel rises at a rate of 1 per second and then immediately repeating the ABI.13 Participants with ‚â•20% drop in the ABI in either leg are eligible. Additional methods of confirming the presence of PAD through angiographic evidence or vascular laboratory testing are summarized in Table¬†2.
Information regarding medical history and demographic characteristics are obtained by questionnaires administered by research staff.

sec.title: Run‚ÄêIn Period
sec.p: Before randomization, potential participants are asked to complete a run‚Äêin period for up to 14‚Äâdays. During the run‚Äêin, participants receive the study application (app) on a smartphone and are asked to enter all food consumed into the app. A smartphone with data plan is provided to participants who do not have their own. Successful completion of the run‚Äêin is defined as entering >800 kcal for at least 5‚Äâdays. Individuals who do not meet this criterion are not eligible. This helps ensure that randomized participants are willing and able to use the study app regularly.

sec.title: Randomization
sec.p: Participants unwilling to adhere to the intervention and follow‚Äêup testing, regardless of group assignment, are not randomized. To ensure equipoise, participants are informed of the purpose of the trial and advised that if they are randomized to the exercise group, they should not make changes to their diet, unless advised otherwise by their physician. Potential participants unwilling to continue approximately their same (current) diet if randomized to exercise alone are excluded. Data on participants excluded due to inability to complete run‚Äêin or unwillingness to adhere to the assigned diet and exercise intervention are recorded. For randomization, investigators use permuted block randomization with random block sizes, stratified by site.

sec.title: Interventions
sec.p: The study interventions combine connective mobile technology with a Group Mediated Cognitive Behavioral intervention and remote coaching. The Group Mediated Cognitive Behavioral intervention uses psychological empowerment, social support, and supportive accountability to increase self‚Äêefficacy and subjective well‚Äêbeing to facilitate positive behavioral change in older adults. The intervention for each study group is divided into 3 phases: intensive (months 1‚Äì4), transition (months 5‚Äì6), and maintenance (months 7‚Äì12) (Table¬†3). During the intensive phase, participants meet weekly in a video conference (Zoom) with other participants in their group and the study coach. Group meetings occur twice per month during the transition phase and once per month during the maintenance phase. All participants receive a manual, a custom smartphone app that is specific to their group assignment, and an ActiGraph accelerometer. Participants randomized to exercise alone receive an app that only tracks exercise but does not track calorie or fat consumption or weight loss. In both groups, participants receive individual coaching calls during the weeks without a group session (Table¬†4).

caption.p: Intervention Summary and Frequency of Contact

tr.td: PROVE study app to record dietary intake (WL+EX only)

fn.p: GCMB indicates group‚Äêmediated cognitive behavioral; EX, exercise; WL+EX, weight loss plus exercise; and PROVE, Promote Weight Loss in Obese PAD Patients to Prevent Mobility Loss.

caption.p: Items Used to Monitor Fidelity to the Study Intervention

tr.td: Uses active and reflective listening to generate the most appropriate responses and questions
Uses nonjudgmental curiosity and uses open‚Äêended questions
Discusses adherence to weighing and self‚Äêmonitoring

fn.p: EX indicates exercise; and WL+EX, weight loss plus exercise.

sec.title: Exercise Intervention
sec.p: The exercise (EX) component in each group is identical and modeled after the GOALS (Group‚ÄêOriented Arterial Leg Study) and LITE (Low Intensity Exercise Intervention in PAD) home‚Äêbased exercise interventions.14, 15 GOALS used a group‚Äêmediated cognitive behavioral framework to help participants with PAD adhere to a home‚Äêbased walking exercise program and improved 6‚Äêminute walk distance, compared with the control group.16 Participants are asked to walk for exercise 5‚Äâdays/wk, beginning with 10 to 15‚Äâminutes of walking exercise/session and working up to 40 to 50‚Äâminutes/session. Exercise is tracked in the study app. Exercise goals are individualized and intended to increase walking duration by 5‚Äâminutes per session each week to facilitate progress toward the goal of 40 to 50‚Äâminutes of walking exercise per session.

Participants are instructed to walk for exercise at a pace that elicits moderate to severe ischemic leg symptoms.15 Walking duration and intensity are monitored using an ActiGraph accelerometer. Before the start of the intervention, participants are instructed to wear the ActiGraph while walking for exercise for 5‚Äâminutes at a pace eliciting moderate‚Äêto‚Äêsevere discomfort defined as attaining ischemic leg discomfort of 4 to 5 on a 1 to 5 scale, where 5 is the most severe ischemic leg symptoms. The ActiGraph‚Äêmeasured intensity (activity counts) during this walking activity is the desired intensity during walking exercise activity. The ActiGraph‚Äêmeasured walking exercise intensity corresponding to ischemic leg discomfort of 4 to 5 on the 1 to 5 scale is remeasured at scheduled intervals, every 3‚Äâmonths, for each participant and after hospitalizations or major illness.

Participants wear the ActiGraph during walking exercise and data are uploaded to CentrePoint. Walking progress is displayed on the study app to the participant (Figure¬†1) and on the study website to the coach. The coach and participant use the data to monitor exercise intensity, frequency, and minutes of exercise per session.

caption.title: Screenshot of PROVE Trial app showing progress toward walking exercise goal for a participant in the exercise (EX) group.
caption.p: PROVE indicates Promote Weight Loss in Obese PAD Patients to Prevent Mobility Loss.

sec.p: During each group Zoom session, the coach presents a topic of the week, such as ‚Äúovercoming negative thoughts,‚Äù ‚Äúgoal setting and self‚Äêmonitoring,‚Äù or ‚Äúwalking exercise in cold weather.‚Äù The coach leads group discussions that facilitate participants sharing their experiences in the walking exercise program, including successes and challenges. At the end of each session, each participant selects their individual walking exercise goals for the next week.

sec.title: Weight Loss Plus Exercise Intervention
sec.p: The exercise component of the weight loss plus exercise (WL+EX) intervention is the same as that described for the EX intervention above.

Participants randomized to WL+EX receive a digital scale and a version of the app that enables participants to track their daily dietary intake (Figure¬†2A) and weight, in addition to walking exercise. The app provides immediate feedback to participants regarding their adherence to self‚Äêselected goals related to daily intake of kilocalories, total grams of fat and protein, body weight, and walking exercise (Figure¬†2B). The PROVE Trial app has been successfully used previously to achieve weight loss in adults with overweight and obesity who did not have PAD.17, 18, 19

caption.title: Screenshots of progress toward walking exercise and dietary intake goals in the PROVE Trial app for a participant in the weight loss plus exercise (WL+EX) group.
caption.p: A, Shows examples of food entered in the app and progress toward dietary goals. B, Shows progress toward exercise goals. PROVE indicates Promote Weight Loss in Obese PAD Patients to Prevent Mobility Loss.

sec.p: The weight loss component of the WL+EX intervention is designed to reduce calorie intake to achieve ‚âà0.3‚Äâkg/wk of weight loss for months 1 to 6 and maintain weight loss during months 7 to 12, with the goal of attaining weight loss of 7% to 10% at 12‚Äêmonth follow‚Äêup, compared with baseline. An individualized reduced‚Äêkilocalorie goal is determined for each participant according to baseline weight. Participants are encouraged to consume ‚âà15% to 20% of kilocalories from protein and <7% of kilocalories from saturated fat. These 2 dietary components are monitored using the PROVE Trial app and coach dashboard. Participants are coached on increasing dietary protein‚Äêrich foods if self‚Äêselected intake is inadequate.

sec.title: Monitoring Intervention Adherence
sec.p: Throughout the intervention, coaches remotely monitor each participant's progress at least once/wk using the coaching dashboard that displays walking exercise relative to goals for all participants. For those assigned to WL+EX, the dashboard also displays weight, nutrient, and calorie consumption relative to goals (Figure¬†2A). This information is used to provide individualized feedback during individual coaching calls.

For all participants, the coach contacts participants outside of their normally scheduled calls for the following: (1) the participant is not recording any exercise minutes for >4‚Äâdays; (2) exercise minutes in 1‚Äâweek are >50% less than the participant's walking exercise goal; (3) the participant has difficulty adhering to walking exercise activity at the desired intensity (ie, not walking at a pace that elicits moderate‚Äêto‚Äêsevere ischemic leg symptoms) at least 4 to 5‚Äâdays per week. Individuals in either group who meet 1 or more of these criteria may receive additional unscheduled individual calls from the coach, as appropriate. For WL+EX the coach additionally contacts the participant between weekly scheduled interactions if dashboard data show 1 or more of the following: (1) absence of self‚Äêmonitoring for >4‚Äâdays, (2) overly rapid weight loss (>1.36 kg [‚âà3 pounds]/wk for 3 consecutive weeks); (3) a 2‚Äêweek period without at least 0.23‚Äâkg [0.50 pounds] weight loss/wk (ie, 0.46‚Äâkg [1.0 pound] per 2‚Äâweeks) (this monitoring begins in week 3 of the intervention); or (4) nutritional concerns (ie, inadequate protein intake). If a participant randomized to WL+EX does not lose weight for a 3‚Äêweek period and they are adherent to dietary goals, the calorie goal is reduced.

sec.title: Monitoring Intervention Fidelity
sec.p: Group meetings and individual coaching calls are audio recorded and a 10% subsample of sessions is selected quarterly by the Data Coordinating Center for review. Investigators evaluate and rate assigned sessions using a fidelity checklist (Table¬†5). Coaches with a mean score of <70% undergo additional training and recertification.

caption.p: Outcomes of the PROVE Trial. For Each Outcome, We Hypothesize That Weight Loss Plus Exercise (WL+EX) Will Have Greater Improvement, Compared With Exercise (EX)

fn.p: EX indicates exercise; IL, interleukin; PGC, peroxisome proliferator‚Äêactivated receptor‚Äêgamma coactivator; PROMIS, Patient‚ÄêReported Outcomes Measurement Information System; PROVE, Promote Weight Loss in Obese PAD Patients to Prevent Mobility Loss; TNF, tumor necrosis factor; WIQ, Walking Impairment Questionnaire; and WL+EX, weight loss plus exercise.

sec.title: Outcomes
sec.p: Outcomes are shown in Table¬†5. Outcome assessors are blinded to group assignment. Outcome assessors at each site are trained in data collection by the principal investigator's (MMM) staff and certified by the principal investigator or her designee, using a detailed checklist developed for the study protocol. Study coordinators undergo recertification approximately every 6‚Äâmonths. When deficiencies are identified, interviewers are retrained and reassessed.

sec.title: 6‚ÄêMinute Walk
sec.p: In the 6‚Äêminute walk, participants walk back and forth along a 100‚Äêft hallway for 6‚Äâminutes after standardized instructions are read from a script. The script instructs participants to complete as many laps as possible during the 6‚Äâminutes. The primary outcome is the total distance covered during the 6‚Äâminutes. The BORG scale of perceived exertion is administered at the end of the walk to evaluate perceived effort at baseline and follow‚Äêup.

sec.title: Questionnaires
sec.p: Health‚Äêrelated quality of life is assessed with the Patient‚ÄêReported Outcomes Measurement Information System mobility questionnaire20 and the Walking Impairment Questionnaire.21 Leg symptoms are assessed with the San Diego Claudication Questionnaire.22 Frequency of exercise activity at baseline and follow‚Äêup is collected via administered questionnaires.

sec.title: Physical Activity
sec.p: Physical activity during daily life is measured over 10‚Äâdays at baseline and follow‚Äêup, using the ActiGraph accelerometer. Up to 7‚Äâdays of wear time will be used in analyses. Participants are instructed to put on the ActiGraph when they wake up and take it off when they go to sleep, removing it only for bathing.

sec.title: Dietary Assessment
sec.p: The standard semi‚Äêquantitative food frequency questionnaire, the Diet History Questionnaire III,23 is used to estimate energy, macronutrient, and micronutrient intake at baseline and 12‚Äêmonth follow‚Äêup.

sec.title: Short Physical Performance Battery
sec.p: The short physical performance battery is a composite score (range 0‚Äì12, 12‚Äâ=‚Äâbest) that includes assessment of 4‚Äêmeter walking velocity at usual pace, standing balance, and time required to stand 5 times from a seated position.24, 25 Each of the 3 short physical performance battery components is scored on a 0 to 4 scale. The 4‚Äêm walking velocity is performed by asking the participant to walk ‚âà16 feet in a corridor at their usual pace, as if they are ‚Äúwalking down the street to go to the store.‚Äù The time required to walk the first 4 m is recorded. The measure is performed twice, and the faster time is used in analyses. Standing balance is measured by asking participants to hold 3 separate standing positions for 10 s each. The 3 standing positions are side‚Äêby‚Äêside stand, semi‚Äêtandem stand, and the tandem stand. Time required to stand from a seated position 5 times as fast as possible is also measured.

sec.title: Height, Weight, and Waist Circumference
sec.p: Height and weight and waist circumference are measured at baseline using standard procedures. Weight and waist circumference are repeated at 6‚Äê and 12‚Äêmonth follow‚Äêup.

sec.title: Muscle Biopsies
sec.p: For an exploratory‚Äêspecific aim, 50 participants randomized at Northwestern undergo muscle biopsies. Gastrocnemius muscle biopsy measures consist of mitochondrial activity (cytochrome c oxidase activity), mitochondrial biogenesis (peroxisome proliferator‚Äêactivated receptor‚Äêgamma coactivator enzyme activity), mitochondrial biogenesis (PGC‚Äê1Œ±), capillary density (capillaries per muscle fiber), calf muscle inflammation (interleukin‚Äê6, tumor necrosis factor‚ÄêŒ±, and interleukin‚Äê1Œ≤), and abundance of senescent cells, compared with EX. These measures will help delineate biologic pathways that may mediate improved 6‚Äêminute walk distance in response to WL+EX, compared with EX. Gastrocnemius muscle biopsies are obtained from an incision in the medial head of the gastrocnemius muscle in the leg with lower ABI, at ‚âà67% of the distance between the medial malleolus and the medial aspect of the proximal tibia.26 Biopsies are performed at baseline and 12‚Äâmonth follow‚Äêup, with the 12‚Äêmonth biopsy incision performed adjacent to the site of the baseline biopsy, denoted by the incision scar.

sec.title: Statistical Considerations
sec.p: Comparisons will be made by using contrasts at 12‚Äâmonths in a mixed‚Äêmodel repeated measures analysis of covariance model with an unstructured covariance matrix to account for the fact that multiple measurements within a participant over time are not independent. We focus on the contrast at 12‚Äâmonths because our interest is on that time point. However, including all time points (ie, 6 and 12 months) will allow us to borrow strength across the time points when there may be missing data at 12 months. Predictor variables as fixed effects will include treatment (EX versus WL+EX), time (6 versus 12‚Äâmonths), and the baseline (prerandomization) value of the end point being analyzed. Field center and recruitment wave within center will be included as random effects. All participants will be asked to complete follow‚Äêup testing, regardless of adherence to their intervention. Tests of hypotheses and reported P values will be 2‚Äêsided using the intention‚Äêto‚Äêtreat principle at the 5% level. We have 1 primary outcome, 5 secondary outcomes, and 7 exploratory outcomes. We do not plan an explicit adjustment for multiplicity for multiple outcomes. However, we will make explicit the number of outcomes explored. Subgroups of interest defined a priori include sex, race or ethnicity (Black versus non‚ÄêBlack), baseline BMI (median split), baseline 6‚Äêminutes walk performance (median split), baseline smoking status (current versus never and past), age (median split), presence/absence of diabetes, ABI <0.6 versus ‚â•0.6, presence/absence of classical claudication symptoms, and presence/absence of exertional leg symptoms.

To account for correlation of baseline and follow‚Äêup, we used data from GOALS16 to estimate residual SDs after adjustment for the baseline level of the response and correlations. For the primary outcome of the 6‚Äêminute walk distance, the root mean squared error was 63.0‚Äâm. For the calculation of power, we used a 2‚Äêsample t test and assumed a sample size of 212 participants, a 12‚Äêmonth retention of at least 85% (a net sample size of at least 180), and 2‚Äêsided tests at the 5% level. To account for the group‚Äêbased intervention delivery, we calculated the design effect, which is the ratio of variances comparing a simple randomized design to a cluster randomized design as 1+ICC[n‚àí1], where n is the size of each group and ICC is the interclass correlation coefficient. The design effect is also the ratio of effective sample sizes for designs where the subjects are randomized independently compared with a group‚Äêrandomized design.27 In the GOALS study, we delivered the intervention in a group setting and we used data from that study to estimate the ICC within a group for 6‚Äêminute walk at 12‚Äâmonths as 0.0297. We assumed a similar ICC for the PROVE Trial and an average cluster size of 7 (the most we expect) to get a design effect of 1+0.0297 [7‚àí1] =1.178. Therefore, we have assumed an effective sample size of 212√ó0.85/1.178=152.9 to account for loss to follow‚Äêup and clustering. Power for the primary outcome is 0.681 for a difference of at least 25‚Äâm in the 6‚Äêminute walk test and goes up to 0.83 for 30‚Äâm, 0.925 for 35‚Äâm, and 0.973 for 40‚Äâm. Note that these power estimates are slightly conservative as we will borrow strength from the 6‚Äêmonth visit in our mixed model. Meaningful change has been defined for change in 6‚Äêminute walk performance: a 20‚Äê to 30‚Äêm change in the 6‚Äêminute walk represents a small meaningful change, and 50 m represents a large meaningful change.28, 29, 30 The GOALS Trial achieved a 53.5‚Äêm difference in 6‚Äêminute walk between the intervention and control groups.16 We believe that WL+EX will achieve at least 60% of the benefit of the home exercise alone, or 32.1 m. Our own (unpublished) pilot study demonstrated an improvement of 64.1 m (95% CI, 10.6‚Äì118) over 7‚Äâweeks. Therefore, we believe that WL+EX will improve 6‚Äêminute walk distance by at least 30‚Äâm over EX.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Among people with PAD who have overweight or obesity, the PROVE Trial will examine whether a diet and weight loss intervention combined with walking exercise results in significantly greater improvement in 6‚Äêminute walk distance at 12‚Äêmonth follow‚Äêup, compared with walking exercise alone. There are at least 3 potential mechanisms by which weight loss could improve walking outcomes in people with overweight or obesity and PAD. First, in individuals with PAD with overweight/obesity, weight loss may improve walking performance by reducing the energy or perceived effort required during the 6‚Äêminute walk. Second, weight loss in people with PAD with overweight/obesity may improve adherence to regular walking exercise, thereby facilitating greater response to a walking exercise intervention. Third, based on preclinical evidence, weight loss may improve the pathophysiologic changes that characterize PAD. Pathophysiologic changes may include improved lower extremity perfusion,31 improved skeletal muscle mitochondrial bioenergetics, and/or reduced inflammation, which may have direct adverse effects on muscle,32, 33, 34, 35 thereby improving walking performance. For example, in a rat model of PAD, obese rats, when compared with rats that were not obese, had hind limb arterial vasoconstriction and reduced vasodilation in response to nitric oxide.31, 33

However, there are several potential reasons that weight loss may not improve walking performance in people with PAD with overweight/obesity. First, in older people, including people with PAD, weight loss has been associated with loss of skeletal muscle.36, 37, 38 In a longitudinal observational study of 389 people with PAD and mean BMI of 28.1 (SD, 5.1) at baseline, people who engaged in intentional weight loss had significantly greater decline in calf muscle area, measured by computed tomography scan, at 3.23‚Äâyears (SD, 1.37) follow‚Äêup, compared with those who did not engage in intentional weight loss.36 People with PAD already have reduced calf muscle area compared with those without PAD.6, 39 Weight loss that exacerbates sarcopenia could be detrimental for people with PAD. Second, although recent literature40 indicates that attending to multiple health behaviors simultaneously can be beneficial and create a synergistic effect on positive health behavior, it is unclear whether these synergistic effects will also be observed in individuals with PAD. Third, while weight loss initially relies on dietary changes, physical activity is often necessary to realize weight loss maintenance, which may be challenging in this often physically inactive population.41 Fourth, the added burden of discomfort, pain, and heaviness that individuals with PAD with overweight or obesity may experience may make behavior change to attain weight loss more difficult compared with people without PAD who have overweight or obesity. For participants randomized to WL+EX, extreme difficulty making the behavior changes in diet or lack of perceived success could discourage progress or sustained engagement in the intervention.

It is also possible that the technological component of the study interventions may be too burdensome for some participants. However, the app has been used successfully to support physical activity and weight loss in other studies, and weight loss has been achieved in prior clinical trials of people who are overweight and obese and who have metabolic syndrome.17, 18, 19, 40, 42, 43, 44 If the WL+EX group sufficiently improves physical functioning above that of EX alone, investigators will have established an additional intervention that could improve the lives of some individuals with PAD without undue burden of additional in‚Äêperson health care visits.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The PROVE Trial is a multicentered randomized clinical trial that will evaluate the effect of weight loss combined with home‚Äêbased walking exercise, compared with home‚Äêbased walking exercise alone on walking performance in individuals with PAD. If the proposed hypotheses are supported, the PROVE Trial will have important implications for the large and growing number of people with PAD who have overweight or obesity.

sec.title: Source of Funding
sec.p: This study is funded by National Heart Lung and Blood Institute, UH3HL141729 (PI McDermott) and U24HL141732 (PI Ambrosius) and supported in part by the Intramural Research Program of the National Institute on Aging, National Institutes of Health.

sec.title: Disclosures
sec.p: Dr. McDermott reported receiving research funding from Regeneron and Helixmith and other research support from ArtAssist, Chromadex, ReserveAge, Mars Company, and personal feeds from Cambrain biopharma. Dr. Spring reported receiving research funding from Actigraph scientific advisory board.
